note.body: Merged. Thanks for your help.

Yeah. I was considering this, although cmakedefine appears to dislike you using CMAKE_PROJECT_VERSION_xxx or PROJECT_VERSION_xxx and considers them to be always undefined.

It is actually a bit simpler though, so updating.

push_data.commit_title: refactor(article): remove part vs article check done in memory

note.body:
There's a workaround that could avoid defining empty variables in Linux.

In top CMakeLists.txt, define VERSION variables like this:

    set(VERSION_MAJOR ${CMAKE_PROJECT_VERSION_MAJOR})

Then use it in config-cmake.h.in:

    #cmakedefine VERSION_MAJOR @VERSION_MAJOR@

Hopefully, this simplifies the code in `panrc.rc`
@ddumont this is ready to go. builds and installs on windows

target_title: PAN 0.146 crashes with (pan:20145): GLib-ERROR **: 09:44:06.196: ../../../../glib/gmem.c:170: failed to allocate 1048576 bytes

note.body: no answer, Closing. Feel free to reopen if this is still a problem

target_title: PAN 0.146 crashes with (pan:20145): GLib-ERROR **: 09:44:06.196: ../../../../glib/gmem.c:170: failed to allocate 1048576 bytes

note.body: David replied no by [mail](https://lists.nongnu.org/archive/html/pan-users/2024-11/msg00011.html), closing.
David, do you still have this problem after removing and reloading this group ?
Closing as suggested by Dave

Hi


> Dominique Dumont <https://gitlab.gnome.org/ddumont> commented <https://
> gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/pan/-/issues/195#note_2275860>:
>
> What make you say that PAN_HOME is ignored and ~/.pan2 is used ?

The data held in PAN_HOME is not used - PAN behaves as though it's a new
installation with no data.

> Looking at the code <https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/pan/-/blob/master/
> pan/general/file-util.cc?ref_type=heads#L86>, I think you may have
> problem is the USB (or drive) is mounted *after* pan is started. Is that
> the case ?

It's not a USB drive - it's a permanently installed SATA drive and it's
mounted at boot time.

Anyway, as I said, if no-one else is having this problem, best close it
as I have resolved it by simply creating a link from .pan2 to the folder
pointed to by PAN_HOME. That works perfectly :)

On the plus side, I'd like to point out that this version of PAN is way
faster and seems slicker than the old one (from Ubuntu 16.04) that I was
using before - unexpected bonus :)

<details><summary>...</summary>

On 14/11/2024 18:51, Dominique Dumont (@ddumont) wrote:

</details>

What make you say that PAN_HOME is ignored and ~/.pan2 is used ?

Looking at the [code](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/pan/-/blob/master/pan/general/file-util.cc?ref_type=heads#L86), I think you may have problem is the USB (or drive) is mounted **after** pan is started. Is that the case ?

On Manjaro (Arch based), if I plug a USB stick in it goes to `/run/media/USERNAME/Kingston`, for example (nothing I have changed, it's been like this since day one). Likewise with external USB drives. Whether or not that place is cleaned up at boot is not something I have ever considered. But couldn't external/extra drives be mounted under `/home` somewhere? Or is that an even worse idea? I seem to recall someone said something about that on the Manjaro forum, that it was possible, but I have never had the need to change anything so I didn't really cared much.
If in doubt, the Arch Wiki should be able to tell you. It's the number one place to go for info, for Manjaro users as well:
https://wiki.archlinux.org/

push_data.commit_title: nzb: use DB to create XML segment parts

note.body:
On Arch Linux, it seems to be the standard. I've only just started using
this distro, so I'm not that familiar with it. Agreed, you'd certainly
think twice about doing it for something you want permanent in Debian etc.

After a slightly closer look: AFAICS discs picked up during first boot
are in
/mnt whilst those found/mounted later are in /run/media/[username]/.
"Run" on this system is not a tmpfs:
run             4.2G  1.4M  4.2G   1% /run

BTW - it's not a USB disc - I have 3 internal hard drives on this PC,
for "historical reasons".

Anyway, as I think I said, if no-one else has this issue, I'll close it,
because what I've done is working perfectly.

D

On Arch Linux, it seems to be the standard. I've only just started using
this distro, so I'm not that familiar with it. Agreed, you'd certainly
think twice about doing it for something you want permanent in Debian etc.

After a slightly closer look: discs picked up during first boot are in
/mnt whilst those found/mounted later are in /run/media/[username]/.
"Run" on this system is not a tmpfs:
run             4.2G  1.4M  4.2G   1% /run

BTW - it's not a USB disc - I have 3 internal hard drives on this PC,
for "historical reasons".

Anyway, as I think I said, if no-one else has this issue, I'll close it,
because what I've done is working perfectly.

On 02/11/2024 19:16, Dominique Dumont (@ddumont) wrote:
> Dominique Dumont <https://gitlab.gnome.org/ddumont> commented on a 
> discussion <https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/pan/-/issues/195#note_2263168>:
> 
> Using /run to mount a drive may not be a good idea. On my Debian 
> system, /run is a tmpfs. According to FHS, /run is cleaned up on boot.
> 
> Usually, usb devices are mounted dynamically under /media
> 
> HTH
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitLab <https:// 
> gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/pan/-/issues/195#note_2263168>.
> You're receiving this email because of your account on gitlab.gnome.org 
> <https://gitlab.gnome.org>. Unsubscribe <https://gitlab.gnome.org/-/ 
> sent_notifications/f663fcfe84927d3301841f2905e3fe07/unsubscribe> from 
> this thread · Manage all notifications <https://gitlab.gnome.org/-/ 
> profile/notifications> · Help <https://gitlab.gnome.org/help>
>

</details>

Using /run to mount a drive may not be a good idea. On my Debian system, /run is a tmpfs. According to FHS, /run is cleaned up on boot.

Usually, usb devices are mounted dynamically under /media

HTH

target_title: Issue finding icu-uc when building on macOS

note.body:
Update: Not sure what happened (macOS 15.1 update?) but generic /opt/homebrew/opt/icu4c alias is now gone. In order for cmake to work, must recreate the alias to point to icu4c@76 or use this instead:

`export PKG_CONFIG_PATH="/opt/homebrew/opt/icu4c@76/lib/pkgconfig":$PKG_CONFIG_PATH`

Edit: Was part of the update from @75 to @76. For me, that was 31 Oct.

Hi Dominique

I've actually solved the issue by simply creating a symbolic link from
-pan2 to the folder I want to use (from the home disc of the previous OS
on this machine).

It's:
Arch Linux rolling, kernel 6.6.58-1-lts & Gnome 47
ASRock 970 Pro3 R2.0
AMD FX™-8320 × 8

The command is
	export PAN_HOME="/run/media/dave/Home3/dave/.pan2"
and printev shows
	PAN_HOME=/run/media/dave/Home3/dave/.pan2
as you'd expect.

If no-one else has this issue, I'll assume it's something odd on m,y
system and close it - as I say, it's no longer a problem :)

Dave

note.body: I wonder if this line is still useful. Could you check ?

target_title: Revert "fix: Removed manual folding of Face and X-Face headers." + removed "Start Minimized"

note.body:
I wasn't certain whether the setting was supposed to still work using another system, hence why I didn't remove it. I suppose that there is indeed none.

>Yes, but D-Bus and libnotify are specific to Linux.

[Libnotify is available through MSYS2](https://packages.msys2.org/packages/mingw-w64-x86_64-libnotify), although I have yet to see if it works on Windows.

> This also causes another, bigger issue; the "Start Pan minimized" setting still exists, but the status icon doesn't. If that option is ticked, Pan starts silently and cannot be used at all. The preferences must be manually edited to disable the setting.

That's unfortunate. I'll remove this option.

> Are D-Bus or Libnotify supposed to replace the status icon or am I missing something? Either way, there's nothing on Windows in 0.159+.

Yes, but D-Bus and libnotify are specific to Linux.

Hi, no "system tray indicator" support is planned as the concept of minimizing applications to such a place is already flawed. If you want to run apps without a window, you could minimize that window.

note.body: Thank you @ddumont & @sid as this issue is now resolved. It appears that Pan sometimes may need to clear out older messages at times if the "local message storage" gets corrupted.

I tried out "delete selected group Article", which cleared out all the articles for that group and that appears to have fixed it. It may be that Pan's info related to that group was corrupted. I will close this issue as resolved.

It's possible that Pan's information related to comp.lang.c are corrupted.

Could you try to "delete selected group Article" ? (right click on comp.lang.c, bottom line of the popup menu)

HTH

```
Aborted
```

I then uninstalled this package and went back to the `pan` AUR package. I still have the same issue in the OP.

I'm heavily against doxing myself, which I believe I will be by giving out that information.

I'm still having the same issue I reported a month ago in the OP and that is happening on Artix Linux.

Just for a comparison, I just now booted up an Arch Linux system, updated pan to the latest version I reported the issue with, v0.160, and it does not have this same issue. What I do notice on Arch Linux is that the "blue triangle" does appear but then quickly disappears as pan then lets me read that article.

I tested this on both systems in the `comp.lang.c group`, both installed pan from the same AUR package, and they are using the same news server to access usenet.

Any suggestions on how to provide non-doxing information to you to help resolve this issue which appears to be only happening on this computer I'm typing on right now?

push_data.commit_title: article: manage subject only in DB
article: manage author only in DB

note.body:
That specific issue that prompted me to write the request should be fixed, but as commented above there are other ways the tarballs can change hash (like if Gitlab changes their gzip version and it starts generating slightly different files).

Also, one of the most common problems we see are with projects that re-tag minor release fixes using the same version number.

The safer move is to generate static release assets using a release action, that way the tarballs are generated, uploaded, and should not change again.
